title.narrative: Social Impact Management Graduate Programme for Sustainable Climate Smart Conservation Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
**Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form.**
In the months before the application for TMT, Embedding Impact had identified that the field of Social Impact Management (incl. Measurement) would be exponentially growing, both nationally in South Africa and globally. A quick analysis of the professionals in this field would learn that (a) the vast majority is at a senior level; and (b) the majority is based in Europe, UK or northern America.
Both are problematic, as the build-up of the available professionals in any industry would be considered with a balance between entry-level graduates, juniors and up to seniors and executive level. A specific training trajectory was necessary to address this aspect, as Social Impact Management currently is at best a standard course within a field of study at universities and not (_yet_!) a major.
Whereas the majority of development funding from Europe and the US & Canada finds its way to Africa, the evaluation of the impact of these funds is largely left to specialists from these countries. From a Social Impact Management perspective, it would be essential to behave impact informed by those that experience it, and therefore having Social Impact Management specialists that intrinsically understand the plight and circumstances of beneficiary communities would be quintessential.
In the context of South Africa, which was experiencing the highest level of youth unemployment at the time of starting the TMT (which has been made worse by Covid-19), the question of employability stands out as one of the reasons why many of our young people struggle to secure long-term employment. Our solution goes well beyond addressing these two components, as work readiness is a key component of our training programme to develop a holistic talent with grit, a field that our partner The Experience Factory specializes in. Furthermore, we created an avenue to create jobs.
By completing this programme we have successfully contributed to all these challenges and aspects, although we would have liked for most graduates to be permanently employed upon completion. This is however only going to be a matter of time.
From an Embedding Impact perspective, as one of the implementing partners, we have been approached in the period July 2021 till mid-September 2021 (the date of submission of this report) for and by:
a) Development of a sector-wide SIM Graduate Programme for the Renewable Industry
b) Assistance for development of the basic elements for SIM for 15 commercial consumer brands, and how to execute the measurement in due course
c) Addressing the needs of medium-to-large size NGOs that are desperate to understand what Social Impact means and are at a loss on how to measure and manage it
d) At least three impact investment funds that are in need to understand social impact and how to incorporate the measurement into their metrics for evaluating investments (pre-funding and post-funding).
As a result, we have offered 3 of the graduates of the programme a temporary contract to assist in alleviating the most pressing pressures in our organisation.
In addition to all of this, the completed programme _also_ had a specific focus on the environmental development space, based on the model of the Environmental Sustainability Agency (ESA). It was foreseen that funding developments for and by ESA would have yielded success by the time of closure. And as much as it has been confirmed, the actual funding has not yet been reflected and such the graduates can’t be employed, as much as everyone wants it. As a sub-sector within the SIM industry, which is by all accounts also growing globally, the programme will add to an increased understanding of what social impact means and how to effectively measure it.
**How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? **
The assistance of TMT couldn’t have come at a more relevant and apt time. As small but growing businesses, Embedding Impact, The Experience Factory and Environmental Sustainability Agency, did not have the ability to divert revenue into the execution of a training module such as we did. TMT provided the essential support that allowed all project partners to participate and take an acceptable investment risk without jeopardizing the future of any of the businesses.
The investment in this small but dedicated programme allowed us to have a holistic approach to development, both a nuclear level with each of the graduates, but also at a macro level by addressing systemic challenges within the eco-system of social impact management services and within natural resource management. All these objectives have been met.
Notwithstanding the fact that not every graduate that started the programme managed to complete it, all of them at least have fully participated and benefitted from a personal development programme. Some of them concluded that Social Impact Management will not be their profession. And whilst this doesn’t directly contribute to the objective of having more SIM professionals available, it is a result in itself. For those graduates, it is a tool to sharpen their own exes, as knowing what you don’t want is an important element in knowing what you want. But it also helps us in sharpening our own axes when it comes to recruitment and selection of candidates going forward.
**Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.**
1. Teams of recent graduates would need experienced and daily/weekly in-situ supervision/management; relying on self-management leads to free-rider tendencies, developmental delays and sub-maximum delivery on project objectives.
2. The curriculum is effective and relevant, as is demonstrated by the fact that the graduates are of value to host organisations during the graduate programme, but also directly afterwards.
3. Deployment of graduates in remote/rural areas would require that their work equipment is up to standards. Relying on second-hand laptops and not having a reliable internet connection brings a level of unnecessary risk of losing the graduates during the course of the programme.
4. Working with three partners that all deliver a different yet equally important element of the curriculum, would require more detailed planning of the training programme and more effective communication between partners.
5. To effectively manage the graduates and the implementing partners, a dedicated manager, who has knowledge of all three aspects, would be recommended.
6. The sourcing, recruitment and selection of eligible candidates require at least 6 weeks, but preferably 8 weeks.
7. Graduates with a degree that has direct touchpoints to Social Impact Management seem to be a better match. These are for instance Development Studies; Environmental Management Studies; Sociology; Development Finance;
Graduates with a background in other studies, with no touchpoints, need more time to understand certain matters. But also seem to be easier swayed to leave the programme when other opportunities arise.
8. It would however be good for the Social Impact Management profession to have a better understanding of how other professions can be incorporated, by means of clarifying those aspects of SIM that are of relevance to them.
9. In particular, the technical aspects of Social Impact Management, with a focus on understanding somewhat more advanced mathematical calculations and economic concepts, seem to be a huge hurdle for some of them. It would be recommendable to see to what extent the programme can be split into a more technical approach and an approach whereby the social aspects of interacting with communities are at the forefront. Both aspects are equally important, but giving graduates a choice in this would potentially lead to broader interest and uptake.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
**SIM Graduates completing 4-week training programme**
The training was designed to develop grads understanding of the current socio-economic and environmental situation at each site to inform the baseline studies to be conducted at community sites they live, to learn and apply their knowledge.
Training entailed:
- Improved understanding of Natural Resource Management and the Wildlife Economy - Corporate literacy - Social Impact Measurement (SIM)
The end goal was to see the graduates being absorbed permanently in any organization partners and contribute meaningfully to the development of their communities by measuring the impacts these initiatives have to their communities.
**SIM Graduates working at sites**
- Graduates were deployed to work for Environmental Sustainability Agency and Property point sites to apply the Social Impact Methodology on the projects allocated to them. the Social Impact Methodology including: Stakeholder Mapping, Data Collection and Data Analysis, as well as Social Value creation.
**SIM Graduates coming from host Communities **
- Graduates that were deployed to Environmental Sustainability Agency were coming from the 3 host communities, Mayibuye Community, Baphiring Community and Barokologadi Community.
**Baseline studies Completed**
- All the graduates has completed their story of change Report for their projects and presented their findings on the 30 August 2021. 6 graduates presented

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 02-11-2021: Although we didn't work towards a specific goal in terms of number (%) of women in the programme, we know from our previous programmes that we on average have 80% or more women that make it through the selection procedure.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 02-11-2021: This include the candidates that have been trained under the Nuffic programme, but were placed with an organisation that was not part of the initial partnership!

title.narrative: B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: 1st: we shifted to a 4-weeks programme on site instead of at our own offices. This was largely due to Covid-19 restrictions, but also to ensure additional support for the graduates by means of maximizing the intensity of the interactions. We also added physical activities in the form of hikes to the curriculum to add to the team building. 2nd: We provided additional support through ad-hoc internet support and by going through a lesson as needed.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: For profit organisations: - Environmental Sustainability Agency (ESA) - Embedding Impact (EI) Not-for-profit organisations - Property Point - Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization (LAEO)

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: We have had in-depth interviews and discussions with 8 out of the 9 graduates that completed the Corporate Literacy Programme. Although we know that the 9th person appreciated the CLP and learned as much as the others, he left the programme too early into the work to claim the changes of new knowledge and skills.
